name: Spacious BR: Downtown/Little Italy
description: Hello! My 2 story top floor apartment has high vaulted ceilings, tons of natural light & views of the San Diego Bay!  It is centrally located in Little Italy/Downtown, walking distance from great shops, bars & restaurants and has easy freeway access. Enjoy a clean & comfortable stay with tons of amenities! ******NEWLY REMODELED******* Updated Photos Coming Soon!!! Kitchen & Bath: NEW GRANITE COUNTER-TOPS NEW KITCHEN APPLIANCES (stainless/black) NEW FLOORING (zebrawood toned) NEW CABINETRY (dark espresso toned) NEW MODERN FIXTURES (plumbing/lighting) NEW WASHER/DRYER (Laundry Room) Entire Unit: NEW PAINT (two-toned: warm w/white trim) and more... •Private bedroom in 2 story 2BR/1BA apartment plus loft •Spiral staircase in living room leads to an open loft space upstairs (additional guest room/office) •Balcony with views of the San Diego Bay •Full size washer/dryer, dishwasher and microwave in unit •Bathroom has dual sinks and over-sized garden tub •Comfortably fits 1-2 in bedroom •Heate
overview: Little Italy is charming!  It is a very cute, friendly neighborhood with so much to do within walking distance.  Just steps away are numerous restaurants (mostly Italian, of course!), bars and shops.  I love them all and  would recommend the following: Isola and NaPizza (pizza); Bencotto (pasta); Kettner Exchange, Juniper & Ivy, and Prepkitchen (American); Ironsides (seafood); El Camino (Mexican/brunch); Burger Lounge (burgers); Pappalecco (coffee/gelato); Davanti (wine); Craft & Commerce (cocktails); Waterfront (dive bar); Bottlecraft (beer).   Little Italy provides you all the conveniences of downtown life (no car needed, but close proximity to highways if driving), but is also removed enough that you can enjoy peace and quiet.  Must do's within walking distance (or if preferred, trolley or cab): the famous Gaslamp Quarter, San Diego Harbor, Seaport Village, Petco Park (Padres baseball), Coronado Island (via ferry), Balboa Park, USS Midway Museum and more!  The San Diego Zoo and Sea

name: Sunny 2BR PRIME Williamsburg w/VIEW!  MIN 30nights
description: BRIGHT, airy, modern apt with large windows, balcony/rooftop access & GREAT view of Manhattan! BEST location to experience the Brooklyn lifestyle, dining/nightlife, 5min walk to Bedford L train (1 stop to Manhattan) and 3 blocks from Whole Foods. ***Central AC/heat*** TV with Movies/Sports channels and WIFI. New building! Hello there,  Our home has 2 bedrooms with queen sized beds, big closets and desks if you need to get some work done. Both bedrooms have a gorgeous view of the Williamsburg bridge and the Manhattan skyline. One of them has a private balcony which is a perfect place to enjoy a morning coffee or an evening drink. The cozy living room has a sofa-bed that can comfortably accommodate two more guests, where you can also enjoy a big screen TV with Verizon FIOS HD Preferred package (Sport channels, Cartoon channels, HBO, Cinemax, Starz, Showtime, Epix etc...) and a vast collection of Blu-rays and online streaming such as Netflix and HULU Plus for movie fans. Like video games!
overview: We are happy to say that we live in the most desirable neighborhood in Brooklyn and we would love to share the experience with you. Very safe and minutes from the L train (Bedford stop), you are in the center of it all, with the best bars, restaurants and stores, all within walking distance. Across the street is the legendary Nitehawk cinema (where you can watch a movie enjoying a drink and dinner), a delicious local Italian restaurant and also an awesome bar with cool live music every night! There is no shortage of entertainment in this lively neighborhood.   Want to shop? Our apt is steps to Bedford Avenue and Grand Street, which host great fashion boutiques, furniture stores, and more.  Stroll to the waterfront and check out the flea market on Sundays or Mcarren Park for a little relaxation or to buy fresh produce at the farmers market.  We know you will love this vibrant neighborhood as much as we do!
rules: We expect our guests to treat our home like theirs! We care a lot about our place!!! Keep the bass down, no outside guests unless mentioned in AirBnb messages, and please tidy the place up on your way out. We love pets but we know that our furry friends can behave a little differently when out of their environment, so please no pets! If you like to smoke, it is ok, but please do not smoke indoors, do so at the balcony and enjoy the view.  ***No Drugs*** Thanks for respecting our home.

name: Perfect for the Budget Traveler!
description: Beautiful, spacious, and sunlit apartment in the heart of the city! Located between historic Capitol Hill and the vibrant H Street corridor, and only a few blocks from Union Station (Amtrak, MARC, Metro). This is a great option for the budget traveler! We're all about transparency for a mutually enjoyable experience.  Your room is a clean and well-lit loft in this airy and sunlit apartment.  The loft is separated from the rest of the apartment by a half-wall (which you can see in the photo). If you look over the half-wall, you look right down into the living room and can see out the windows.  The loft is all yours while you're here, and we hope you consider the rest of our apartment your home while in D.C.   The bathroom is shared, and to get to it you have to go through our bedroom. We promise to keep this totally not-weird.  Again, this is your home while you're here! We think you'll like it. Everything! The apartment is fully furnished for your enjoyment.  Free internet and Netflix,

overview: This is honestly the BEST location in DC for any tourist (family or otherwise) or business traveler. We are literally a 2 min walk to the Woodley Park/Zoo metro stop (Red Line). The National Zoo is practically in our back yard; it's not only free but the grounds open at 8am and it's a great place for a run or early morning walk. There's a pharmacy one block away and because this is a big convention area (we have the Marriott Wardman and the Omni Shoreham down the street), there are endless restaurants of every variety. For a younger crowd and great bars/clubs/nightlife, Adams Morgan is a 10-minute walk or a two-minute bus ride away.  There's also a wonderful farmer's market in Dupont Circle every Sun about a half mile away. You can pick up a tour bus 5 minutes from here or metro/bicycle/taxi/drive to virtually every tourist destination within minutes. We also live in an historic neighborhood which is wonderful to explore and the National Cathedral (with lovely gardens) is just up the h

overview: South Pasadena is a small town amid the hustle and bustle of the City of LA. With it's charming craftsman style homes, big yards and family friendly vibe, it's one of the safest neighborhoods in Southern California. Just 3.5 square miles, South Pasadena is home to 3 elementary schools, 1 Middle School, 1 High School and one 1 Catholic K-8th school. Walking to school is a big deal for the neighborhood kids so don't be surprised to see throngs of little ones waddling down the street with their backpacks in tow! We've also seen a growing trend among boutique restaurants and cafe's in the city. South Pasadena is home to the award winning, French restaurant Bistro de la Gar. In addition, we have a wonderful tapas-style restaurant called Aro Latin, an Irish pub with amazing guinness pie, shephers pie and many imports on tap. For the kids, we have Menchies frozen yogurt and Mix and Munch - the grilled cheese and cereal bar. On Thursday evenings, the farmers market is in full swing. Anything f

Plus the famous SF Cable Car passes right by my apartment  and you can hop on one-block away. This is the perfect place for a quick getaway to SF. My place is good for couples, solo adventurers, and business travelers. Here's the secret to why my place is actually super cool. There's rooftop access (Even though technically we're not allowed by the building). But grab two of the fold out chair and take them up to the roof and enjoy the beautiful bay and downtown SF. Alternately, you can also hang out on the fire escape with the two chairs. You will have to squeeze through the window and artfully adjust the chairs on the wood plank. overview: My apartment is located in the famous Chinatown neighborhood of San Francisco. It's right at the bottom of Lower Nob Hill and Chinatown. Take a walk down Grant Ave when you get a chance and check out the different store and shops, it's the most famous Chinatown street in SF. It's only a few blocks away. You can check out the Cable Car Museum which is just around the corner. I also recommend grabbing a coffee and hanging out at the Gallery Cafe just across the street from the Cable Car Museum, it's really funky and homey as well. Take a walk to Little Italy, which again is just around the corner. Grab a late night dinner at one of the famous Italian restaurants or grab lunch at Molinari's sandwich shop on a lazy afternoon and walk to Washington Square Park and take a seat on the grass next to the Saint Peter and Paul Church. You won't regret it!

Little Italy provides you all the conveniences of downtown living, but is also removed enough that you will enjoy a peaceful stay. Our Los Angeles home is a restored 1930's spacious one bedroom apartment in a tri-plex I own with my two brothers. There is a window air conditioning unit in this room for when it gets to hot for comfort. Also, we have a Pack'n'Play for those with small children. overview: Our neighborhood is at the southeast corner of  Korea-Town, south of Echo Park and Silverlake and just west of Downtown. The first suburb of downtown Los Angeles, there are many historic buildings and architectural treasures. MacArthur Park is a 5 minute walk down from our hill with a small lake to walk around, soccer field, playgrounds and an amphitheater with summer concert series. There are a lot of Central American families living here and some great little restaurants... but the gem in Los Angeles' restaurant crown is Langer's Deli which was voted best Deli in America some time back - order sandwich #19!! Note* This is one of the few neighborhoods next to downtown that hasn't been gentrified yet. We think this is a good thing but feel it's important to point it out so as to manage expectations. If you are looking for hipster coffee and cupcake shops this isn't the Airbnb for you. If you want a real slice of LA life, Bienvenido:)
rules: This is our family home and we only ask that you take care of it as you would of your own. My brothers also live in the building so please be kind, courteous and quiet. There are two separate entrances; the stairwell at the front houses our father's paintings and though they may not be worth much in the art world, they are priceless to us. If you use this entrance you must always be certain it is locked, even when you are home. The second entrance is the back stairwell through the side gate where the parking is, we would appreciate if you used this entrance as it is the safest, quietest and most private of the two. (please be sure to open and shut this gate quietly as it can make a good deal of noise. Thanks)

overview: NoMad, short for “North of Madison Square Park,” is the latest New York neighborhood to get portmanteau’ed. And like Soho and Tribeca, which were shabby commercial districts before they became artists’ enclaves, NoMad is becoming a luxury-housing magnet. Among the new condos that are gleaming like sequins in this longtime hub of the wholesale garment industry is 212 Fifth Avenue, a 48-unit condo conversion at West 26th Street from a team led by the developer Madison Equities. Like many NoMad edifices, No. 212 has a vaguely medieval style—indeed, the views from some of its apartments are of a façade adorned with sword-clasping knights. But NoMad is coming out of the Dark Ages and into the light. “This was a commercial area, and that kind of worked against it for a while,” says Efraim Tessler, an associate broker with Keller Williams New York City. “But New Yorkers are always looking for a hidden gem.” In another telltale sign, rentals are going condo, like at 88 and 90 Lexington Avenue,

description: Stay comfortably in the center of old Boston, stepping out into Beacon Hill's gaslit lanes. Stroll the Common, the Freedom Trail, and the Esplanade on your way to nearby culture, events, and dining – and get anywhere in Boston and Cambridge quickly. Original mahogany floors, persian rugs, vintage furniture, nine windows with views over the rooftops of Beacon Hill – settle in to my top floor apartment to watch the sunset, or walk minutes to the Esplanade to see the regattas on the Charles River. Sleep one on the day bed in the living room, and two in the full bed in the bedroom. Enjoy AC in the bedroom and fans throughout the rest of the apartment. Accessibility note: Beacon Hill brownstones don't have elevators and my flat is on the top floor. The place is yours to enjoy. Help yourself to staples in my pantry, dishes, towels, shower supplies, and books and magazines to entertain you. I have multiple closets with space for your gear and will leave drawers open for your use. I'll be here
overview: Once the home of Wendell Phillips, Henry Thoreau, and Daniel Webster, a hub on the Underground Railroad, and site of one of the first integrated public schools, Beacon Hill is now home to everyone from John Kerry, Suffolk University students, nurses at nearby Mass General Hospital, and to up-and-coming professionals like me! Tree-lined, gas-lit cobblestone streets lead to pocket parks, quaint shopping on Charles Street, the Common (the oldest American park) and its elegant public garden, and to Boston's famous Esplanade. Visit the African-American History Museum a few blocks a way and tour the African-American Heritage Trail to learn the stories of one of the coolest neighborhoods in Boston. Boston's Freedom Trail picks up a few blocks away, Cambridge is a single stop up the Red Line, and the North End is within walking distance.
rules: Please remove your shoes as you enter the apartment. Please respect my neighbors and honor my home – no parties, no "guests", no drugs, no orgies, no pets, no beer pong, no dinosaurs.

overview: Carroll Gardens is a very pleasant, quiet, community-oriented neighborhood, close to Manhattan, that includes some of the City's best restaurants. It is one of my favorite neighborhoods in Brooklyn. Clean, very safe. (The 'Mob" still lurks, so you are safe prancing down the street at 3am tipsy with heels and headphones on and no one will touch you. No crime at all. Heaven for the ladies, total freedom!) Smith St is less than a block away and famous for its food, bars and shops. Park Natural (best local organic food store) and Union Market (great premium grocery store with prepared foods, etc.) are 3 blocks away. My friend Kelly's favorite tui na (Chinese massage, if you haven't done it, do and you'll never pay for a western massage again!) is 1 block away. (Disclosure: Some of this text lifted from my friend Kelly's airbnb page – she lives up the block ;)
rules: My home is my sanctuary. I've made it really nice and comfortable for your (and my) pleasure. Thank you.

description: This sunny 1BR on the top floor of a two-story Victorian features a deck, a yard, and a modern kitchen.  The location is smack-dab in the middle of the bustling Mission District, steps away from nightlife and great restaurants and with great access to public transit—it’s just two blocks from the 24th & Mission BART station. The apartment is between Mission & Valencia Streets. The extra-high ceilings and period detail make a striking contrast with the modern furniture and contemporary art. The southern-exposure living room fills up with light during the day and looks out over the nightlife of the Mission at night, while the bedroom is tucked away from the street and remains quite quiet. The comfortable queen-sized bed is perfect for a couple or solo traveler, and the expansive built-in desk would suit two people working side-by-side. Remodel

overview: The Mission has it all! Our home is in the middle of a vibrant, diverse neighborhood. From coffee shops to restaurants serving burritos, pupusas, Belgian, Vietnamese, Indian, Chinese food - the list goes on and on! From bakeries to bars to live music venues.  We live at the end of a short street in the "eye of the storm," so to speak. The street is quiet and calm and my neighbors are great!  The Mission is a bustling and very "urban" part of the city. As in the rest of San Francisco, some people will ask you for money, some people are homeless. These people don't tend to be violent. Mostly what happens here are crimes of opportunity - phones left out, bags unzipped, etc. So don't be scared - be aware!  Here are some of the places we like best: Restaurants: Chinese - Mission Chinese on Mission St  Vietnamese - Sunshine @ 16th & Valencia  Indian pizza - Zante - really yummy! a bit far away @ Mission & Cortland (take the 14 or the 49 S)  More cafes, coffee shops, and cool bars than I can
rules: This is our home and we ask that you treat it as if it were your own. Please limit your water usage as much as possible - shorter showers, efficient dishwashing, etc. California thanks you!! ~ We recycle, reduce and reuse wherever possible. I am happy to provide restaurant and entertainment options, advice on navigating the
overview: Greenwich Village....there have been books written about it, it has been portrayed in movies. It is very special and if you stay here, you'll be living in the West Village like a local. The home of poets, free thinkers, writers, artists, political activists, Greenwich Village used to be an actual village in the late 17th and early 18th century when the only part of Manhattan that was settled was the very southern tip. Now upscale and chichi, the architecture and the people keep this special neighborhood beautiful and charming. There is no end to the shopping, dining and entertainment options you have. Storied jazz clubs like the Blue Note, Smalls Jazz Club, the Comedy Cellar and Sullivans are within walking distance. Yet the few blocks around the apartment are residential and quiet. You'll have the best of both worlds.
rules: Pets are welcome. Smoking is permitted. However, there is an extra 50 cleaning fee for either pets or smoking. But the most important rule is that you are comfortable and happy in the apartment. If you are not, please call me!

While there are some great new restaurants just around the corner, the street and immediate area feels very "neighborhood" - more locals, less tourists...and that's what's to love about it.  At the end of the street there is McGorlick park complete with dog park, weekend farmer's market and the most beautiful tree canopy.  And 10 minutes away is McCarren Park with a fully lit running track (very popular, even late night) and the edge of Williamsburg with more restaurant selection.

overview: Check out Airbnb's unbiased opinion of this amazing community! https://www.airbnb.com/locations/new-york/greenpoint  Greenpoint is a charming, hip & safe neighborhood in northwestern Brooklyn - and provides a great place from which to explore the broader NYC area. It is relatively low-key (less gentrified than neighboring Williamsburg) but offers a range of things to do, which is why I moved here after living in Williamsburg, TriBeCa, Midtown & Soho. It has eastern European (mainly Polish) influences and is full of young people & families alike. There are dozens of restaurants, bars, coffee & convenience shops, as well as a lovely green space (Transmitter Park), which has sweeping views of the Manhattan skyline. I am more than happy to share suggestions based on your interests.
rules: I expect the same respect that I give during all of my Airbnb stays! Please remove shoes in the foyer & keep noise to a minimum. You are welcome to utilize the space (including kitchenwares, blankets, etc), but please leave my personal belongings (clothing, etc.) on their own.

An Italian restaurant called Fumo is located on the corner of 139th, a new sports bar serving burgers is on the corner of 140th and The Grange is located on the corner of 141st. If you want to stray a bit further from home, you are a quick 5-minute car ride to the world-famous French Quarter (the city's most famous bars, restaurants, shopping and architecture), Frenchman Street (a collection of the city's hottest live jazz venues) and City Park (1,300 acres of pristine parks, putt-putt golf, New Orleans Museum of Modern Art,etc). overview: Harlem is a really cool neighborhood that gives you the feel of what all of NYC used to be like: a mix of rich and poor; it is multi-cultural; full of artists and writers and normal young people who are trying to enjoy and create in this city without 6 figure jobs. There is Jackie Robinson Park, the Apollo Theater, and many other sites that are worth exploring. CUNY and Columbia University are also nearby.

overview: Harlem is known internationally as the Mecca of the African diaspora, but Harlem has been home to many different identities including the Dutch, Irish, German, Italian, and Jewish. Harlem was originally settled by the Dutch in 1658, but was largely farmland and undeveloped territory for approximately 200 years. As New York’s population grew, residential and commercial expansion moved northward, and development of the Harlem territory was inevitable. During the 1880’s, elevated rail lines were extended north along Eight & Ninth Avenues, encouraging expansion northward. Development of transportation lines caused speculation on the land and many fine row houses and multiple family apartment buildings were erected. However, this boom slowed in 1893 when a national recession struck. The recession curbed further developed and stymied real estate sales. When the economy recovered in 1895, development continued, especially in the form of beautiful apartment buildings. Located on 123rd street,

overview: Just one block away is a cluster of gourmet restaurants that often make it on the national 'Best Restaurant or Best Bartender' lists, including Beast, Expatriate, as well as Extracto Coffee (some of the best beans roasted in Portland). Alberta Street is a funky strip of boutiques, art galleries, and great places to eat and drink just 3 blocks away. In summer months on Last Thursdays, the street closes to car traffic in the evening to allow for a free flowing art festival/street fair where the weirdest, most creative and unique parts of Portland unite to celebrate free expression and art of all kinds. Check out our Guidebook to see a full list of our neighborhood faves. The parks in Portland are also amazing. Theres at least one in every neighborhood - usually with beautiful towering trees and big green spaces. Grab a picnic at New Seasons Market and head outside! You can borrow our picnic blanket. :) Many parks have movies or concerts in the park during the summer months.
rules: We live above the apartment and noise flows pretty easily between floors. overview: The Neighborhood: Sugar Hill and Hamilton Heights have long been desirable neighborhoods. Hamilton Heights is named for Alexander Hamilton. Hamilton's country home, The Grange, was located on his estate just south of 145th Street. Today The Grange is part of the National Parks system and can be visited at the north end of St. Nicholas Park.  During the Harlem Renaissance, African Americans made their mark on NYC as they had never been permitted to do so before. And when they could afford it, they wanted to buy a brownstone up on the hill -- everything would be sweet then -- thus - Sugar Hill.

overview: Inwood is one of the best kept secrets in all of New York City, and is perfect for visitors to NYC who desire access to green parks, historical monuments and museums without having to “leave” their neighborhood. It is accessible by the express A train, which reached 207th street (where this apartment is located) in the 1930s. Many of the neighborhood’s buildings are historical in nature as they have strong Art Deco characteristics. You will rarely find a "new" building in Inwood - it feels authentically NYC! The neighborhood remains one the greenest in all of Manhattan, with The Cloisters in Fort Tyron Park, The Hudson River (with views of New Jersey), Inwood Hill Park (containing Columbia University’s sport fields) and smaller parks Isham Park, Sherman Creek Park (Swindler Cove), Fort Washington Park, Fort Tryon Park, and Highbridge Park all within walking di

It doesn't get much easier to explore Los Angeles than from this location.  NOTE: The bedroom has a pi

In fact, you cannot even get into my apartment building without driving or walking past this grocery store, that's how close it is.  Across the street you'll find a cool selection of coffee shops and restaurants -- including Starbucks, Le Pain Quotidien, Tender Greens, Ruth's Chris Steakhouse, Rubio's, Burger Lounge, and more. overview: Gold coast dining at Hugo's frog bar, Gibson's, Carmine's and more.  For years, Rush Street and Division Street in Chicago’s swanky Gold Coast neighborhood has been a popular hangout for all sorts of crowds, especially on the weekends. On any given night, you can count on plenty of partying alongside college kids, bachelor and bachelorette parties, older businessmen from out of town enjoying the city, and of course all of those that come in from the ‘burbs. Here you’re not going to find any fancy high-end nightclubs selling 10 beers and 500 bottles of Grey Goose Vodka. The whole block is lined with relatively small, homey, local bars where everyone shares the same intentions: to have some drinks, socialize, people-watch, and have a good time. If you’re heading to Chicago for a night out, check out this neighborhood.

Both places offer delivery.  Fuel America in Chestnut Hill is a hip, new place with good coffee and offers a really chill and relaxing space for people looking to do some computer work. CafeNation in Brighton Center as well as Athan's are both laptop friendly cafes as well. For food shopping we recommend Trader Joe's in Coolidge Corner or Newton (both ca. 15 min away by car), although there are a number of convenience stores and places to buy produce within walking distance. description: Our carefully-remodeled downstairs apartment has a gorgeous bathroom & kitchenette, big windows and a separate entrance that opens onto a shady side yard and sunny patio.   It's on a quiet, leafy street a short walk from lots of great restaurants. This is a bright and cheerful, newly-remodeled basement apartment.  With a separate entrance, 8' ceilings, hardwood floors, a gas fireplace, a Murphy bed, a nicely-appointed kitchenette, custom built-ins and a sparkling bathroom, it's the perfect place for a couple to visit Portland on a budget.   It opens up to a beautifully landscaped yard with plenty of trees and a vegetable garden.  Adventurous guests can rent our bicycles through Spinlister and our car through Getaround. description: This serene and spacious Garden Apartment is in a newly remodeled San Francisco Victorian located at the award-winning Quesada Gardens. Stay in the heart of Bayview, a neighborhood folks are buzzing about, and enjoy easy access to a world class City. You'll love this spacious Garden Apartment in a unique San Francisco neighborhood. All that San Francisco has to offer is close, some areas very close ... downtown, ballpark, the Mission District, South of Market (SOMA), Museum District (Yerba Buena) to name a few. Your garden apartment boasts all the comforts of home with the ambiance of a homespun resort. The interior has been redesigned by my friend and awesome local designer Dane Robert Wilson who is a magician at building on existing features to create visually interesting and immediately relaxing spaces. overview: Like any "transitional" urban neighborhood, Bayview isn't for everyone. It feels rough around the edges to some. If you prefer controlled environments and tourist-ready sites, consider well-known neighborhoods (and pay more). A stay at Quesada Gardens in Bayview offers an experience with a "real" San Francisco residential neighborhood in an interesting time of change.  Folks still wonder why it took so long for Bayview to be discovered. Even now, some native San Franciscans are surprised to find the best weather in the City, beautiful homes from every era since Victorian times, stunning hills with sweeping Bay Area views, unique “Maker Economy" businesses, and a tight-knit community creating its future. Is it safe?  Of course, you should be cautious as you explore any SF neighborhood, or really any city. Visitors to Bayview are statistically safer than in other neighborhoods, but sometimes report they don't "feel" safe.  (More often, people say they were surprised about how good their

Just down the hill is the famous Ballast Point Brewery, as well as the acclaimed breakfast spot, Rose Donuts and a Starbucks. There is also a great Thai spot and wine &cheese bar. For those needing transportation the same center also has a Trolley station. Not too far from that is one of SD's best Mexican Taco shops as well as the acclaimed Fashion Valley mall an several chain restaurant staples such as The Cheesecake Factory. overview: Awesome, centrally located neighborhood. The area is called University City or "UTC" for short.  Minutes from beautiful La Jolla, and just 10 minutes south of Del Mar, a very hip beach town (amongst many in Ssn Diego).  It's a 1/2 mile from an enormous shopping center, transit center and Starbucks.  I know a few UBER drivers personally, and if they are working, they can be here in minutes.  There are tons of cool little restaurants.  5 miles from a major beach, minutes away from the two main freeways in San Diego (5 & 805).  Most of all, this is an incredibly safe neighborhood, and the complex has 24 hour security, and Northeastern Division Headquarters for the San Diego Police Department is right across the street!
rules: My house rules are very simple:  1.  Absolutely no drugs, not even 420. 2.  You will have a key to the apartment-please don't lose it, if you do, there is a 75 lost key fine which is payable to me, in cash.  I've had too many of my guests lose keys and it costs me 75 to have the doors re-keyed. 3.  Be respectful 4.  Clean up after yourself 5.  Be nice to my cat 6.  Have a sense of humor-I love to laugh! Smoking is fine. (Cigarettes)-but due to complex rules, which I personally find ridiculous & I'm not a smoker, you have to smoke off-site.  All you have to do is stand on the sidewalk, which is maybe 50 feet from the apartment.  If you aren't from California you will find that a majority of places, including bars and restaurants are smoke free in California.  As for alcohol that's fine-San Diego is known for its craft beer.  I'm not much of a drinker, but I'm a great designated driver.

It's the perfect spot to look out towards the ships in the bay and have a morning coffee. overview: Just a short walk up the hill from the bustling Mission District, we're in the heart of Bernal Heights, a charming neighborhood atop Bernal Hill.  Our house is two blocks from Cortland Ave, where you can try some of San Francisco's best kept gastronomical secrets: Red Hill station for seafood, Piqueo's authentic Peruvian, and Bernal Star for outdoor movies while you enjoy a burger and beer. Or, you can always grab some fresh provisions at Good Life Grocery or the Epicurean trader.  Other tasty delights include Sandbox Bakery, opened by former Slanted Door and Chez Panisse pastry chef Mutsumi Takehara, Pinhole Coffee opened by Blue Bottle descendents, and Avedano's Meats badass butchery. Explore the succulent greenhouse at none other than Succulence or grab a cocktail in the famous, eccentric backyard garden at Wild Side West.  Once you've quenched your thirst, climb up the majestic trails to the top of Bernal Heights where you'll experience panoramic views of Sutro Tower, the Golden Ga

overview: Loft is located in the heart of the Fabric District. A designers dream of every kind of fabric, trims, threads, and needles. At the end of our street is Santee Alley, 3 blocks of discount shopping. We are 2 blocks from the California Mart and the Ace Hotel.    By day our streets are bustling with activity; shopping, vendors, and the highest foot traffic in Los Angeles. But be aware that our neighborhood is dark and desolate at night. This can be intimidating for some people.  Downtown LA has been called "America's Next Great City" by GQ Magazine. As a longtime resident of downtown, and LA native, I am excited to share the burgeoning of this vibrant area with visitors, travelers, and locals.
rules: - NEIGHBORS : Our building is shared with fabric shops, shoe stores and an art gallery. overview: Just north of downtown Chicago, and nestled against the Lake Michigan shoreline, is the Gold Coast. As the name would imply, the area is one of the country's most affluent neighborhoods. With streets that are lined with historic mansions and specialty boutiques, the Gold Coast is an intensely popular area for residents and visitors. Branching off of The Magnificent Mile is Oak Street, an upscale shopper's dream. The retail revelry includes internationally recognized stores, swanky boutiques and rare, designer fashions. If carrying around loaded shopping bags makes you hungry, you can stop at one of the district's many celebrated restaurants, including Michelin-starred winners and classic Chicago steakhouses. A day of shopping becomes a night of revelry on the neighborhood's fabled Rush Street. Amongst the prestigious hotels and celebrated eateries, you will find a trove of booming nightlife hot spots and high-energy events. Treat yourself to the Gold Coast, you deserve it.

description: Close to 46th st Subway (5 min walk, 4 stops to the city) this place is great for couples, solo adventurers, and business travelers (10min commute to mid-town east/ UES). You'll find laundry, bars, restaurants, cafes, and groceries all within 2 blocks. And you'll be in the center of Astoria, 30th Ave & Steinway, within a 5 min walk. Like any place in NYC, location is king, this is why our place is ideal. You'll be near everything but just enough off the beaten path to get a quiet night sleep. The building, and the apartment, is of fairly new construction and well maintained for a city that’s filled with so many old spaces. Don’t worry you’ll still get plenty of NYC charm from simply walking around the neighborhood, and you won’t need to worry about falling down pre-war stairs.  A true 2 bedroom, with a split floorplan for added privacy, you’ll find it well-lit, clean, and safe. You’ll have access to your own private bedroom, and shared livingroom, kitchen and full bathroom with the hos
overview: The apartment is located about a 5-minute walk to the center of Astoria, so you’ll be close enough to all the action but just far enough for a good night sleep. Astoria is one of the most diverse places in all of New York (and that’s saying A LOT). Here you’ll find an old world charm with the outdoor cafes and small, independent restaurants and shopping scene. The nightlife is just as varied as the daytime, with hookah spots, salsa dancing, beer gardens, and more. Astoria is very much a little community where it’s almost impossible to find a big box store nearby. A historical immigrant neighborhood, what started with Irish and Italian has morphed into a large Greek and North African community. However, in recent years the area has become of interest to Manhattanites adding to the extreme diversity.

description: Walking distance from Griffith Park, the Hollywood strip, and Los Feliz, this 1-bedroom apartment is ideal for a couple or a several friends looking to relax in a groovy apartment while touring around the city. We are a fun and artsy couple in the film business who love our 70s-style abode and would love to share it with you! We're experienced travelers and want to make your stay easy and memorable. This charming, bright and spacious 1-bedroom apartment with a private balcony is tucked away behind Hollywood Blvd. Enjoy our outdoor pool! Full kitchen (waffle-maker, food-processor, toaster, etc.), bathroom, and bedroom with a comfortable California King bed (larger than a King bed, great for tall people). Record player with a huge record collection, flat screen TV, lots of DVDs and VHSs, and board games to keep you occupied during your down time in the city. There is a coin washer and dryer on premises and high speed wi-fi. We also have an air mattress and sofa. Two yoga mats, a BBQ, lot

name: Sunny and quiet private room close to subway (JP)
description: Our apartment is located in Jamaica Plain - a vibrant neighborhood in the city of Boston, full of families, working professionals, musicians & artists. Room is well-sized & has a queen sized bed. 1 minute walk to the bus (39 bus route) & a 5 minute walk to the subway (orange line) - both offering direct & quick access to downtown Boston. Our place is good for couples, solo adventurers, & business travelers looking for a quiet home base that offers easy access to all that Boston has to offer! You will be sharing our apartment with us. Our good-sized guest room can accommodate up to 2 guests. The room is well-lit with two windows, has a new queen-sized bed, a wardrobe, a chest of drawers and a flat screen TV with access to a Roku. The bedroom is located at the back of the apartment away from the other bedrooms giving you more privacy. Guests will share a bathroom with us. There is a bathtub, shower, sink and toilet in the bathroom. Wifi is available for internet throughout the whole apar
overview: Our apartment is located in a quiet street within Jamaica Plain; a fun, diverse and vibrant neighborhood within the city of Boston. Great attractions within walking distance of our apartment include: - The Arnold Arboretum: a beautiful place to go for a walk, hike or cycle. - Jamaica Pond: go for a walk around the pond, or even rent a row boat!  - The Southwest Corridor (this walking and bicycle path runs parallel to the subway line and you can use it to talk safely all the way to downtown Boston). - Sam Adams Brewery - free tours! - Center Street: JP's main shopping street - offers an eclectic mix of shops and food options. Wonderful cafes, bars and restaurants within walking distance of our apartment include: - Weekend Brunch: VeeVee and Center Street Cafe (amazing homemade donuts!) - Burgers: Grass Fed - Ice Cream: JP Licks (the original branch of this Boston favorite is in our neighborhood) and FOMU (wonderful dairy free ice cream) - Asian: Seafood Cafe, Noodle Barn, Wonder Spice C
rules: - Please be careful when coming and going so not to let the cat out. He is usually very curious to leave! - Please keep the noise down from 10pm until 8am. - Guests are not allowed to have other guests come over. - Please be considerate and treat our home with respect. - Check-in is 5.30pm during week-days. Please check with us if you are arriving on a Friday, Saturday or Sunday - we can likely be more flexible. - Checkout time is 11am. Though again we can likely be flexible on this. Please just ask!

name: Quiet and Cozy room in Garden Apartment
description: A great place to retreat, This small and cozy bedroom has allows for a serene and quiet moment in a rich and diverse neighborhood, located in a historic building in the lower east side near subway, galleries, great restaurants and bars. This is apartment is a true gem.  Located in an old brownstone in the lower east side, across from the park and library. This is a quiet place to retreat to. Full kitchen, with washer and dryer and cooking supplies. A large outdoor garden roof deck (that you must climb out the window to get to, but continues to expand). The bedroom is small but quite comfortable. Located in back of apartment, it has a queen bed made of organic latex, cotton bedding, nice sized vintage dresser, a mirror and book shelf for storage. Window looks out to south side of apartment with no one in view. The room doesn't get any direct sun, but has some nice late afternoon light. Additional storage for luggage is available in hallway and closet in adjacent space. There are also ad
overview: All is at your doorstep here, you can get fresh juice and dumplings on the corner, quality fresh food at Dimes, the neighborhood darling, or have a nice dinner at Fat Radish or Skal. Great Bars close by as well, including Clandestinos, 169 and Forget ME Not. As the weather gets warmer, it's easy to walk across the bridge to brookly as we are at the foot of Brooklyn Bridge/Williamsburg Bridge and close to East River Park. There's a citi bike stand right outside if you want to ride around for the day. Adjacent to Chinatown/Soho, the best galleries and shopping in the Lower East Side, historical tours are provided regularly by the Tenement museum just over on Orchard. And close proximity to Essex Market, famous Russ and Daughters, Katz' Deli, The New Museum. Across from the library, gym, and seward park. Safe and friendly neighborhood that still feels like old new york!
rules: This is a small quiet building, we ask guests to be respectful of that. Smoking is not permitted, nor additional guests without prior approval.

name: Your Home Away from Home!
description: Centrally located to all that Chicago has to offer. 15 min bus ride in any direction will take you to museums, the loop, wicker park or most of the music festival venues. Your home away from home The apt is a first floor walk up in a very safe, family friendly neighborhood.  It is near enough to the action that you can drop your bags and immediately head out to explore but also just far enough to relax comfortably without any worry of disrupting city noise. The inside of the apt has plenty of room to relax, and the outside offers even more - free parking (in the rear) and a yard for bbq'ing or playing a game of stick ball.  During the summer months, I host a 'movie in the park' in the large side yard for all of the neighborhood kids and guests are always welcome to join. The bedroom features a comfy full size bed, a medium sized dresser and plenty of closet space for your bags/clothes.  You can hang out in any part of the house you'd like. There is a large living room for relaxing or w
overview: East Ukrainian Village / West Town is a beautifully tree-lined neighborhood, with ornate churches, large historic homes, delicious food, fun bars, cafes and shopping. Hot traditional breakfast is available at Sunrise Cafe, which is just around the corner. Also check out Flo (southwestern style brunch), Atomix (coffee), Bite (veggie friendly), Phil's Last Stand (amazing shrimp po'boy), or Arami (fresh sushi). All within walking distance. Located about a mile away from Wicker Park where there are an endless number of places to shop, eat and more.
rules: Contact Airbnb if you need to make adjustments to your reservation.  -Please ask before inviting anyone in my home. No overnight guests without prior notice. -Please be respectful of noise levels around bedtime, which is typically 12am-7am. -Bathroom: a towel, some soaps, shampoos are supplied.. there are hooks in the bathroom for your towel. Let me know if you have a bathroom schedule. -Kitchen: You are welcome to use any kitchen supplies, just clean up and put things back where you found them after each meal. Be gentle with my pots and pans, clean, dry and return them to their spot, do not leave dishes in the sink. -Bedroom:. Just don't leave any garbage out and I'll take care of the rest. -Smoking only permitted outside. - When checking out: 1.Turn off lights, close windows 2.  Make sure you lock the front door and just drop the key through the mail slot...that's it!

name: Sunny Bedroom in Bushwick Loft
description: This is a private room with a full sized bed in a beautiful loft building.  There are high ceilings and plenty of sunlight, and roof access with a great view.  It's located on the Bushwick/ Bed-Stuy border, close to the J,M,L, and G trains. Booking times are flexible, feel free to message me if interested in longer bookings. This apartment building, built in the early 1900s, retains the original character of the warehouse building it used to be, with restored hardwood floors, wooden beams, painted brick walls, and exposed pipes. You will be staying in a private bedroom and sharing a common area and bathroom with my two wonderful roommates.  You will have full access to the kitchen with a stovetop, oven, fridge, microwave, and dishwasher.  You will also have access to a washer/dryer setup in the building, and a roof deck with a beautiful view of Manhattan. This apartment is located on the Bushwick/Bed-Stuy border. name: Charming 1BR in Brooklyn Heights
description: Enjoy Brooklyn at it's best: brownstones and tree-lined streets, unique dining and craft cocktails, boutiques, Brooklyn Bridge Park and waterfront, and a 5 minute walk to the Marriott in downtown Brooklyn. This room is great for someone who's traveling for work, or looking for an inexpensive visit to New York, and who wants quick access to the city but also have the full "Brooklyn experience." If you want to explore the city during the day, experience our unique nightlife, and then have a quiet and convenient place to come back to at night, this is the spot for you.  Guests have access to the bedroom, bathroom (shared), and should feel free to use the kitchen, appliances, and washer and dryer. I live at the apartment will also be using the common areas. I interact with guests as much or as little as they want, but if you're looking for a private romantic getaway, this isn't the place for you. I'll be around when you check in to make sure you have everything you need, to give you a quic
overview: Brooklyn Heights is a wonderful neighborhood, for many reasons: it's really close to Manhattan, walking distance to the waterfront and Brooklyn Bridge park, 8 subway lines within walking distance, or all the fantastic restaurants, cocktail bars, and boutiques lining Atlantic Avenue, Smith Street, and Court Street. The apartment is also a 7 minute train ride, or 15 minute walk, to Barclay's Center if you are planning to see a game or a concert. overview: The Lower Garden District neighborhood is quiet, green, very walkable, and in a great location within the city. It's a historic neighborhood with old mansions, but also has a growing shopping and cultural area along St. Charles Avenue and Magazine Street. It is easy to reach nearly all parts of the city in 15 minutes or less from this neighborhood by bicycle, car, or the historic streetcar - and we are a short walk from the French Quarter, Warehouse District, Central Business District (CBD), the Irish Channel, and Central City (great for seeing the Zulu Parade and Mardi Gras Indians when Carnival Time comes around). If you want to venture past the Quarter, the Treme, Marigny, and Bywater neighborhoods (some of our favorite parts of the city) are easily reached by bike (there are plenty of places nearby to rent a bike for a good price). name: Big Room w/Private Bath near Train and Nightlife.
description: Stay in my spacious, modern Wicker Park apartment in a large bedroom w/private bath & access to common areas including patio.  I'm located on Wicker Park itself offering plenty of green space & 1/2 mile from the 606 walk/run/bike trail. Trendy restaurants and shops are within 1 block. I'm 2 blocks from the Damen Blue Line stop which provides easy access to O'Hare and downtown.  The "El" train is directly behind the bldg, be aware of noise. Earplugs provided! I have 2 cats that live here. Beautifully decorated and LOCATION, LOCATION, LOCATION!  I live here because frankly it doesn't get much better than this in the city.  I'm on an upscale residential street in one of the trendiest neighborhoods of the city with access to the park out my front door and the 606 (Bloomingdale Trail) only half mile away.  My favorite restaurants are within a block of here and the El couldn't be closer (admittedly a blessing and a curse). Garage parking available for 15/night starting July 1, 2017. Just re
overview: Wicker Park is awesome.  It's conveniently located in the midst of a bunch of other great neighborhoods like Bucktown, Logan Square, Ukrainian Village, Noble Square and East Village. It's historically been an artsy part of town, but has definitely gotten much more gentrified in the last 10-15 years.  Division Street (2 blocks South of me) reflects the gentrification more and Milwaukee Ave (a block from my place) reflects more of the funky roots.  It's SUPER walkable with lots of great places to shop and eat.  I'm also only 1/2 mile (10 min walk) from the new-ish Bloomingdale Trail (also referred to as "The 606") for biking an walking/running.  This is an elevated 2.7 mile trail built on abandoned train tracks that starts at Marshfield and goes West from there.
rules: Please don't feed the cats or give them anything to drink except water.   Be mindful of cats in your room and make sure not to lock them in your room. Please be respectful in terms of noise if you're coming home late.  You are welcome to the K-cup coffee and tea, but please do not eat my food unless expressly invited to.  Please do not enter my bedroom or open the door. No bringing other guests over during your stay--only the people whose names are on the reservation are permitted in the unit. I am sensitive to chemical fragrances, so please do not spray any cologne, perfume or other chemical products inside the home.

rules: Try to leave shoes at the door & no shoes on rugs.  If you spill anything on the rugs, please clean after yourself. Please separate recyclables from trash & leave bags outside of door at the end of your stay.  If you are planning to stay for a while, leave the trash outside the door every Friday evening.  I will have to make sure to separate the recyclables and trash, NYC has strict recycle rules.   Due to the old design of the plumbing system, I ask that NOTHING other then bodily waste gets flushed down the toilet.  Toilet paper & feminine products has to be disposed into the trash can provided. Keep noise level down to minimum starting 11pm.

description: Close to Brooklyn Botanic Garden, Prospect Park, delicious restaurants, trendy boutiques, grocery stores, wine shops, and the 2 & 5 trains (35mins to Times Sq), this apt has everything you need for an easeful, enjoyable vacation in NYC. Equipped with a queen-sized bed, optional air-mattress, and stocked kitchen. Super spacious, with high-speed wifi, a super comfy bed (its a Leesa), incredibly friendly cats, proximity to many Brooklyn attractions, quality speakers, a guitar, and so much more. overview: My street was voted the most beautiful street in Crown Heights - lovely front yards + stoops and carefully landscaped trees. Also, you'll only be a 15 minute walk from the lovely Prospect Park (even closer to Brooklyn Botanical Garden!), which is a sweet place for a picnic or a long run. description: Safe neighborhood in the northern end of Manhattan. Subway downstairs (A), and 3 blocks away (1). Surrounded by Inwood and Fort Tryon Parks. A short walk  from Hudson River. A door makes this room private. Guests have access to bathroom and kitchen. Inwood and Washington Heights are neighborhoods that emerged in the 1920s with the extension the of subway lines to the north of Manhattan. It was built for the middle class that used the train to shuttle daily to their jobs downtown, so the quality of construction is very good. overview: Inwood and Washington Heights are neighborhoods that emerged in the 1920s with the extension the of subway lines to the north of Manhattan. It was built for the middle class that used the train to shuttle daily to their jobs downtown, so the quality of construction is very good. Ethnically, this area was Jewish and Irish for much of the 20th Century. In the 60s, Cuban immigrants began to move in. As the city went bankrupt in the 70s, crime increased and garbage piled up in the streets. Neighbors left the area opening space for immigrants from the Dominican Republic but the neighborhood has remained pretty mixed. In the last 15 years Inwood has undergone considerable change as Columbia University students, young musicians and artists, and others have moved in, and restaurants and shops have sprouted along the main streets.
rules: Kids 7 and up, welcome!

name: Fun 1 Bedroom in Historic 7th Ward
description: The perfect place for travelers who love a great deal, are looking for the real New Orleans, and like to have room to stretch out in. Close to everything, with the friendly vibe of old New Orleans. A charming one bedroom with room for two couples or three friends, this apartment has a full kitchen, a lovely front porch for people watching, a clawfoot bathtub and lots of historic details like a french window, hard wood floors, high ceilings, and mantels in every room. The first room doubles as a front parlor with a futon that can be made into a double (full sized) bed. The second room of the double parlor is an eat-in kitchen. There is a full closet to hang your clothes and the back room is a quiet bedroom with a queen sized bed. There is also a single studio day bed that can easily fit in either the front room or the bedroom, perfect for a toddler, child or small adult, if three friends want to all have their own bed. As of March 3, 2015, there is a brand new mattress on the queen bed
overview: Anybody in New Orleans will tell you how fiercely loyal people here are to their neighborhoods--and everyone is convinced that theirs is the best, me included. I have lived in the 7th Ward for 13 years, and I've watched as my neighborhood has come back stronger after Katrina (though you will still see the scars of the biggest hurricane in US history), while still keeping the best of the good old days.
rules: Parking: Do not park in the driveway at 1617 N. Rocheblave. They will tow! You can park directly in front of the house between the two brick walkways that go down to the curb. Large bedroom w/queen bed. Wifi, patio, full bath, washer/dryer. Our space has some history, abandoned about 35 years ago this triple decker was a labor of love to renovate, its wooden and warm with a south facing bay window. The back side of Mission Hill (MH) faces southwest and is not inundated with student housing, no huge party scene like the front of MH. Plenty of ethnic and american restaurants and bars abound. Our common space is small, but the bedrooms are good sized. Two of the bedrooms have 2 large windows each and the red room only has one window. overview: My neighborhood is mostly owner occupied housing, it is the result of 30 years of grass roots organizing and a locally responsible Community Development Corporation. I have a decent interaction with many of my neighbors. We have a  4 mile long linear park nearby with a bike path. 2 blocks to the top of the hill there is an old apple orchard and a deeply wooded forest, that can be quite good for watching birds. There are nearby sports fields and playgrounds as well. From the top of Mission Hill one can see most of Boston and even part of the bay. Our location is probably the best thing about this neighborhood.
rules: In the kitchen the primary thing would be to wash your own dishes and clean up after yourself. We don't usually use shoes in the house, we can provide you with slippers or you might want to bring some. Its not a problem if you have to use orthopedic shoes. The bathroom is clean and we want folks to hang up your towels,either in your room or in the bathroom, and not leave the floor wet. We are not a loud house at night. Alcohol is fine so long as you aren't bent on getting drunk. And please no smoking inside, we have plenty of space outdoors for that. If you are here by yourselves for more than 3-4 days we may ask you to water the house plants. We ask that you recycle all pertinent trash and compost your food scraps, if you're not familiar with that we'll be happy to show you our system. No outdoor fires allowed if we are not present. Check in time is best at 3 PM and check out is at noon.

overview: Wide ethnic diversity and close proximity to Manhattan make Astoria one of the best-known Queens neighborhoods, attracting New Yorkers and tourists alike. Astoria is known for its Greek cuisine, and rest assured that the journey to finding a favorite will be a delicious one. Kick back at the Queens Kickshaw and order the grilled cheese of your choice along with a craft beer or cider. Truva Café and Grill is known for its stellar Turkish fare, and Sanford’s is a solid choice for weekday brunch or late-night bites. For something more mobile, follow the aromas to one of the many falafel and shawarma food trucks that dot the neighborhood. There is no shortage of bars in Astoria. The best-known of these watering holes is the Bohemian Beer Hall,  an expansive and jovial outdoor beer garden offering some of Europe’s (and America’s) finest suds on draft and served in large frothy mugs. Sports, pool, and bar games are front and center at Break Bar and Billiards. Parrot Coffee on Ditmars Bouleva

overview: Though some Poles have moved to nearby Ridgewood, Queens, as rents have risen, Greenpoint is still the city’s center of Polish life, with Polish-language signs on doctors’ and lawyers’ offices, pharmacies and photo developers along Manhattan and Nassau Avenues. The eastern leg of the neighborhood, which stretches past McGolrick Park, is home to many recent immigrants, and the descendants of many who came to Greenpoint decades ago. The center of the community is St. Stanislaus Kostka Roman Catholic Church, built in 1903, which has a soaring gray brick steeple. Recent arrivals of another sort — young people spilling over from Williamsburg — have made their own mark on the neighborhood. Franklin Street, which runs parallel to Manhattan Avenue, has developed its own commercial district — albeit smaller — with bars and restaurants, a wine store, coffee shops and clothing boutiques.

overview: Crown Heights has always been a motley fusion of Hasidic and Caribbean, and now it's making its way into hipster lore as the place for the best in Brooklyn coffee, restaurants and street art. Stroll up Nostrand Avenue for chana, roti and other delicacies from our Jamaican and Trinidadian neighbors; head a few blocks towards Kingston Avenue for Jewish pastrami, bagels and a heady fix of people-watching; or move over towards Franklin Avenue for artisanal wood-fire pizza and picklebacks. And did I mention you're right near the subway? And Prospect Park, never a wonder for visitors to New York but a real treat for us locals.

name: Sunny, Cozy Room Near Train, Cafes & Parks
description: Large living space with a private sunny bedroom in trendy Crown Heights, just 20 minutes from Manhattan via express 5 train (just one block away). Experience the fusion of hipster, Caribbean and Hasidic cultures and wander around brownstone Brooklyn; explore Prospect park, Franklin Avenue bars and restaurants, and local underground culture. Ever watched the sun rise over the rooftops of Brooklyn, peeking through the trees to herald in a brand new busy day? I love my large, sun-filled living room for the incredible views, and can't wait to share it with you.  Enjoy your private bedroom with a full size bed, closet, drawers and comfy corner couch, perfect for relaxing on after a long day in New York City. My vegetarian/kosher kitchen is great for cooking meals, making tea or coffee, or grabbing a quick breakfast before hitting the city! We share the space, but your own bedroom is private and features a small corner space for living and hanging out. You're welcome to share the living room
overview: Crown Heights was once known for racial tension, but now a sign of racial integration, as the area fuses its Afro-Carribbean and Hasidic heritage with newcomers thanks to gentrification and plenty of new cafes, bars and restaurants. Waltz down Nostrand Avenue for the best Trinidadian and Jamaican food from authentic hole-in-wall restaurants, or head a few blocks towards the Jewish enclave on Kingston Avenue for New York Jewish pastrami, bagels and the best people watching you'll ever see. Then there's the newfound hipster enclave of Franklin Ave (we have a Starbucks now..), and even a couple cafes nearby on Rogers and Bedford. Get your ultimate #Brooklyn Insta shots by strolling or resting on a bench on nearby Eastern Parkway for people watching and the best New York slice of nature in the middle of a busy parkway. Best of all, Prospect Park is only a 25 minute walk away, and yes, it is better than Central Park and I will tell you why.
rules: No tobacco smoking indoors. My kitchen is kosher / vegetarian however meat cooking can be accommodated if you ask in advance for me to arrange. Please be respectful of the space and leave it as you found out, I'm proud of it and hope you will be too!

description: We live in a historic 2 story Polish flat built in the early 1900 's that features beautiful bay windows, hardwood floors, hotel quality mattresses & vintage furniture. It's a spacious, gorgeously day-lit apartment that is very comfy and welcoming. Casa Roja :)  This 3 bedroom has a kitchen, bathroom, dining room, back porch (includes a hammock!), backyard, and front porch. The back yard has a fire pit and we always have wood for those chilly nights or morning. A futon with a thick matress is available for parties larger than 6. Guests have access to the entire apt. :) We love talking to our guests and we love showing them around town! We do have a very busy work schedule and are not always able to show people around town and sometimes we even come home exhausted and just wanna plummet unto our bed. Of course we understand travelers do feel that way too. We will of course greet you when you come in and show you where everything is! Little Village is an amazing working class neighborhoo
overview: Little Village is an amazing working class neighborhood filled with amazing people who come predominantly from Mexico. Needless to say, it is Chicago's "Little Mexico" and has a culture unto its own which makes it unique from all other Chicago neighborhoods and is especially different (positively so) from the Loop and Downtown areas. It's filled with families and you'll often see kids playing on the streets throughout the day. In the summer and fall it is vibrant with music festivals, community events, and big cultural "Ferias" that celebrate Mexican culture, history, food, and people.  26th Street is Little Village's economic center and it is a wonderful contrast to Downtown's "Magnificent Mile." Filled with mom and pop shops, bakeries, food, and beyond. It will transport you to Latin America. Take a day to walk down the 2 mile stretch of local businesses and make sure to make a few rest stops at the local bakeries, and taquerias.

overview: Hamilton Heights is the home of City College of New York (CCNY), Dance Theatre of Harlem, The Harlem School of the Arts and Aaron Davis Hall. The neighborhood offers several parks, including the recently built Riverbank State Park, embedded in Riverside Park which runs along the Hudson River west of Hamilton Heights. Historic Hamilton Heights comprises the Hamilton Heights Historic District and the Hamilton Heights/Sugar Hill Historic District Extension, both designated by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission. One of the highest hills in Hamilton Heights slopes up from the Hudson River at 155th Street, and contains the Trinity Cemetery. Many individual buildings in the district are also landmarked, including Shepard Hall on the CCNY campus, and the building that once housed The High School of Music & Art. (from Wikipedia)
